document.docAuthor: Drew, R. A. I., Romig, M. C. & Dorji, C.
document.masterDocTitle: Records Of Dacine Fruit Flies And New Species Of Dacus (Diptera: Tephritidae) In Bhutan

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Records Of Dacine Fruit Flies And New Species Of Dacus (Diptera: Tephritidae) In Bhutan

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Dacus longicornis Wiedemann, 1830: 524
; de
Meijere, 1911: 380
;
Bezzi, 1909: 292
. Type locality: Java . Holotype female in ZMUC.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Bactrocera vespoides Doleschall, 1859: 123
. Type locality: Ambon , Indonesia . Holotype male in ZMB.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Mellesis destillatoria Bezzi, 1916: 118
;
Drew et al., 1998: 604
(as syn.). Type locality: Bhamo, Burma . Holotype female in MSNM.

Mellesis eumenoides Bezzi, 1916: 119
;
Drew et al., 1998: 604
(as syn.). Type locality: Tatkon, Burma . Lectotype male in BMNH.

Mellesis bioculata Bezzi, 1919: 437
;
Drew et al., 1998: 604
(as syn.). Type locality: Mt Makiling, Luzon, Philippines . Lectotype male in MSNM.

Callantra vespoides
–
Enderlein, 1920: 358
; Hardy & Adachi, 1954: 169;
Hardy, 1977: 46
(as syn.).

Dacus (Callantra) smieroides
–
Malloch, 1939: 411-412
;
Drew, 1989: 248–249
; White & Elson-Harris, 1994: 317.

Callantra unifasciatus Hardy, 1982: 184–186
;
Drew et al., 1998: 604
(as syn.). Type locality: Wotu, Sulawesi . Holotype male in MBB.

Callantra variegata Wang, 1990: 73
, 76;
Drew et al., 1998: 604
(as syn.). Type locality: Daimonglong, Yunnan , China . Holotype male in IZAS.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined . –
BHUTAN : 1 male , Phuentsholing ,
13 May.2000
, coll. S. Thapa
; 1 male ( 2 Oct.2000 ), 1 male ( 16 Oct.2000 ),
Tsirang ; 1 male (
9 Nov.2004
)
,
1 male (
16 Nov.2004
)
,
Gelephu , Purana Bastey , coll. Maha Prasard & Karma Namgyel
; 2 males ( 2 Nov.2004 ), 1 male ( 23 Nov.2004 ),
Purana Bastey , coll. Karma Namgyel & Maha Prasard. All specimens attracted to cue lure. Specimens in NPPC and QDPI
.

Distribution. –
Widespread across the region from southern Asia to southeast Asia (see Drew et al., 1998 ).

Hosts. –
Wild species in the Family Cucurbitaceae (see Drew et al., 1998 ).

Remarks . – This species has a widespread distribution across southern Asia and southeast Asia and has been regularly misidentified with numerous synonyms being described (see notes above). It has been adequately described and illustrated by Drew et al. (1998) and is best distinguished by the combination of the following characters – red-brown scutum, cells bc and c fuscous, costal band overlapping R 4+5 , face fulvous with a pair of black spots, anatergite fuscous, katatergite yellow, postpronotal lobes mostly yellow, mesopleural stripe narrow (slightly wider than notopleuron dorsally). It has minor pest status.
